description.text: "Large Geared Cube, Motorized Edition" is a larger (2X) version of my "Geared Cube, Motorized Edition" (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:288129), which was based on emmett's "Three Cube Gears" (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:213946). Standing approximately 240mm (9.5") tall and 170mm (6.75") wide, this larger format version was requested by friends and associates as it is much easier to see at a distance during school presentations, exhibitions, etc., as well as in the home. Check out the video for the size comparison with the original version. Video of high speed break in of this thing is here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=23ByThsWH2w. The left cube is the original version, and the right is the 2X version. The green mat upon which both versions rest is 1" resolution. This thing requires both a lot of filament and a lot of time to print, but the end result is worth it for presentations. Designed Sketchup Make 2015. Printed in PLA on an Ultimaker 2 Extended using Cura default settings.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.1mm

Infill:

20%

Notes: .4mm Nozzle. Print "Gear Motor.stl" at 100% infill.

Parts I Purchased: 1) Motor: http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B009N81HES?psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_detailpage_o03_s00. 2) Coaxial Power Jack: Radio Shack part number 274-1583. 3) 3.0 Vdc Power Supply: Radio Shack part number 273-315 with the "N" style plug 273-345, you get one free with the power supply. Tools and supplies I used: 1) Rubber mallet. 2) Small vise. 3) Flat punch set. 4) Modeling knife. 5) Small files. 6) Sandpaper. 7) Slip joint pliers. 8) Needle nose pliers. 9) Thick cyanoacrylate glue. 10) Cyanoacrylate accelerator. Instructions: Print all pieces as shown in "Assembly.skp" or "Assembly.stl". You will need to print: 1) One of "Base.stl". 2) One of "Cube Gear Base.stl". 3) One of "Hub.stl". 4) One of "Gear Hub.stl". 5) One of "Gear Motor.stl". 6) Three of "Cube Gear Large.stl". 7) Four of "Cube Gear Small.stl". 8) Seven of "Pin.stl" I printed the prototype in blue and black. While I broke down the assembly into individual components, by using Cura's editing abilities and the Ultimater 2 Extended's ability to print to the extents of the build plate, I was able to print this thing in three print sessions by combining the individual parts for three build sessions; two for the blue parts, and one for the black parts. If your printer does not print well at the extents of your build plate, I recommend you print the components one at a time. In either event, this is a long, yet easy print. Patience comes to mind. As a test for your printer, it's settings and the colors you use, I recommend starting, as did I, by printing one "Cube Gear Small.stl" and one "Pin.stl". After printing, insert "Pin.stl" into "Cube Gear Small.stl" and make sure it spins freely with little or no effort. If it does not, using your slicer, slightly decrease the size of "Pin.stl" (e.g. by .98) and print then try it again. If it is too loose, slightly increase the size of "Pin.stl" (e.g. by 1.02) and print then try it again. If you cannot easily scale the pins, let me know and I will upload the scaled pins for you. Assemble as per Assembly.skp (or Assembly.stl). Hope you enjoy it, and thanks to those whom requested this large format, it was an enjoyable design and print.

description.text:
This is a customizable clip so you can attach a flashlight to your hardhat, if it is equipped with accessory slots. Instant Headlamp!  
I couldn't find a headlamp that I liked for use with my hardhat at work. The straps that come with most headlamps are ill suited for hard hat use, and most aren't that bright and use AAA batteries. I decided that my lithium 14500 powered Sipik clone was a better light than most head lamps, and thus I decided to attach it to my hardhat.

The included STL fits a Sipik SK-68 clone onto a MSA V-Gard hardhat.  
Measure your flashlight diameter and width of your hardhat slot and either edit the scad file or use customizer.  
Do a test print (I used ABS with 100% infill) and see how it fits in your hardhat. You can adjust several parameters to improve fit:  
Thickness: defines how thick the clip will print; thicker will be stronger, thinner will be more flexible and will help in insertion and removal of your flashlight. I used 2mm.  
Release Tab Length: This sets how big the two insertion wings are. Bigger tabs will help you release your flashlight. 4mm works ok for me.  
Locking Clip Angle: Controls how "bent" the locking tab is. More bend = tighter/snappier fit.  
Locking Clip Reach: This controls how deep into the slot the barb will sit. If the barb isn't quite able to snap into place, increase this value. Likewise, if it looks like you have too much length after insertion, reduce this value. You want the clip to just snap in place when fully seated.  
Locking Clip Barb Size: This sets how big the barb is. Bigger barb=more secure fit. Smaller barb=easier to remove clip from hard hat. 2mm for me results in a snug fit, but removal requires two hands and some effort.

As featured on. http://3dprintingindustry.com/2015/11/05/grow-your-own-produce-indoors-with-avooqs-3d-printable-aquaponics-system/ http://www.treehugger.com/sustainable-product-design/avooq-3d-printable-aquaponics-cascaqua.html http://3dprint.com/103138/3d-printed-cascaqua-aquaponics/ http://3dprint.com/103138/3d-printed-cascaqua-aquaponics/ https://all3dp.com/cascaqua-aquaponic-fish-plants/ CascaquaTM is a Home Aquaponics System released free to the 3D printing community to promote sustainable technology and healthy living. The patent pending CascaquaTM – Cascading Aquaponics System is a closed loop ecologically balanced system that combines the cultivation of plants without soil and the cultivation of fish (hydroponics and aquaculture). It is essentially a mini ecological system where the plants care for the fish and the fish care for the plants symbiotically. Aquaponics is considered the most natural method of growing organic produce as the produce is entirely free of chemicals which surprisingly not all organic produce is. It is also a very effective method of caring for your fish because the filtration system is natural, continuous and it oxygenates the water. The Cascaqua features a sculptural tower of cascading grow beds stacked above a beautifully crafted fish bowl. A quiet pump keeps the water recirculating, the pump sound is completely masked by the tranquil trickling as the water reenters the fish bowl.
Start manufacturing your own Cascaqua free by downloading and 3D printing the Cascaqua parts here. You will also need to source a fish bowl, pump and flexible tube all of which can easily be sourced from Amazon. Parts info:
– 270mm diameter fish bowl with a 170mm diameter opening.
– 300L/hour submersible pump.
– 8mm O.D. flexible tube.
– Printables required qty’s: Cacade planter (qty 5), Outrigger 1 (qty 3), Outrigger 2 (qty 1), Base (qty 1). Note; you may need to adjust the outriggers to suit your fish bowl. Another Avooq Creations, Creation. Find all our printables and instructions at Avooq.com Happy Printing.

comments.text: I understand you may be concerned about 'bacteria' but that is the whole point of the system, the bacteria are what convert the fish waste in to nutrients for the plants. While using untreated waste water [from humans] is dangerous, this type of system is not. Herbs will do well depending on the type, but any leafy green such as rocket or lettuce will go really well. With larger tanks tomatoes work well as well.
comments.author: chukzilla

comments.text: Goldfish need at least 20 gallons to survive.
comments.author: CorbeauCat

comments.text: Ok, a couple of general points, many fish - including goldfish will grow to the size of their tank. That is if you get a small goldfish and put it in a large tank it is more likely to grow to its maximum size, however if you put it in a smaller tank it will not grow as large. Also the size of the tank i.e. volume is only one factor when it comes to the number and type of fish that can be kept, the use of filtration and water flow [for oxygen] also affect the number and size of fish. A tank [say 10 gallons] with good filtration and water flow will be able to support more fish than a tank of the same size with less filtration or water flow. A link to a comprehensive website is here : http://www.firsttankguide.net/capacity.php while my experience keeping fish all through my teenage years and my ongoing engagement with aquaponic systems has contradicted a bit with some of the advice, it seems like a very comprehensive site for people starting out. When it comes to fish in aquaponic systems I would suggest starting with smaller fish such as tetras and/or guppies over large fish such as goldfish. Also bare in mind that once you set the system up it takes a couple of weeks for the good bacteria to get to become established in whatever growth medium you are using for the plants. Once they are established however the system is largely self supporting in regards to keeping the water clean and the plants healthy, you just have to introduce nutrients to the system in the form of fish food.

How to make a lid. I made a lid for a cat food can.
If using flexible filament, make the tolerances very low to none. PLA/ABS needs some tolerance, but it varies from printer to printer.

Objectives Design and print a lid for a can. You will learn what kind of tolerances your printer has, and can apply that to future projects. Audiences Age: 10+
Skill: Low-Intermediate Preparation You will need:
Tin Can
Calipers
Basic Understanding of Tinkercad
(Optional) Flexible Filament Steps
  • Make cylinder, scale to the diameter of the can and a depth of 1mm.
  • Make another cylinder, scale to the diameter of the lip of the can and a depth of 5mm.
  • Move 5mm cylinder up 5mm.
  • Move 1mm cylinder up to the top of the 5mm cylinder and center it.
  • Make both cylinders hole objects.
  • Make another cylinder with a diameter 10mm bigger than the other cylinders, and a depth of 20mm
  • Line everything up
  • Group everything together
  • Download and print.
  • Resize and reprint until you get a perfect fit.
    • Results When everything is finished and fits perfect, you will have a lid for a tin can, and knowledge of your printer's tolerances.

Disclaimer.
I do not have testing equipment to prove that this will reduce the amount of harmful fumes/particles that are given off while printing ABS. But it should help. This air scrubber was designed to take up very little space in the Malyan 180. But should work with other enclosed printers as well. The inspiration for this was derived from my concern for printing ABS filament in my home office.

Printer:

Malyan M180

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2mm

Notes: 10% infill for the elbow and air stand.
90% infill for the collar.

After some initial testing I would recommend using two fans. They create a lot more suction through the cartridge. Make sure your fans will run on the same voltage that your printer will supply. You may need to hack into your other cooling fan/fans. If you do this you are on your own, it will void the warranty on your printer. After you have printed the parts, glue the collar into the top hole with one tab pointing straight down (I used two part epoxy). As long as your gluing stuff, glue a magnet to the back, it will keep the unit from vibrating away from the back of the cabinet. The elbow on the fan helps to circulate the air in the enclosure and maintain a more uniform ambient temperature for printing ABS. You will need some flat head screws 6-32 x 1-1/2" for one fan or 6-32 x 2-1/2" for two fans.
3.5m x 40mm or 3.5 x 65mm. I added a switch to the front of my printer for convenience, but you can just unplug the air scrubber when printing PLA. You will need at lest one fan, search Ebay for 40mm X 40mm X 20mm fans. I found these 2 for under $10.00 You will also need respirator cartridges, search Ebay for 3M 60923. I used some packing foam to make a gasket. Foam gasket. Magnet glued to the back.

I was just learning how to use cad software and so I decided to use basic skills to make something useful and here it is. The 1" label is referring to the outside, not the storage space, so beware of that.

Print the box and lid, and if your printer has good tolerance the lid should fit perfectly. If you upscale too much, the lids tolerance will change, and it will be too loose, so I may add a tighter lid for megascaling.

A bifold wallet designed for flexible filament. My version was printed in NinjaFlex SemiFlex, but others might work. This thing functions just like a traditional bifold wallet and features a space for bills, four horizontal slots for credit cards (that can each hold at least two cards), and two vertical slots for scraps of paper or lesser-used cards. EDIT 2-11-2016
Added a version with rounded corners so it isn't as sharp in your pocket.

Print Settings and Instructions All the wall thicknesses are in increments of 1mm so for the best print I would suggest using a 0.5mm nozzle (or one close to it and telling your slicer that you are using 0.5mm). This way, all the walls will come out as two shells. Set your infill to 100%, although there will be very little that isn't a "shell". You don't need any support at all, but I would suggest using a "brim" if your slicer supports it. I would also suggest setting your slicer to stay within the confines of the print during jumps, as cleaning up thousands of elastic strings is not a pleasurable experience for most.

Simple7 Puzzle This is a nice little puzzle. Not too difficult, but not too easy either. It’s sort of a Goldilocks Puzzle in both size and difficulty! Overall puzzle size is: 6cm x 6cm x 2.5cm (2 3/8" x 2 3/8" x 1") It’s easy to print (Box, Box Top, and a set of 7 Pieces). Requires no supports and minimal, if any, post-print finishing. Some find it quick and easy to solve, while others will find it a little more of a challenge. These little puzzles make great Holiday, or Birthday gifts for anyone who enjoys a good puzzle. They look great and provide at least a modest challenge. Solution: The correct solution requires placing all 7 Pieces into the Box with each Piece lying flat on the bottom of the Box. No Piece can be tilted up at an angle, not even a tiny bit. The Box Top will easily fit back on the Box with all 8 Sticks comfortably inside. Trust me, there is plenty of room in the Box for all 7 Pieces when they are arranged correctly. The puzzle is designed with about 1.0mm slack in both the X and Y dimensions. To make printing easier, I have included a single .stl file with all 7 Puzzle Pieces arranged to print together as a group, and I have provided a single .stl file with both the Box and Box Top arranged together. Of course, I have also provided all of the separate individual .stl files. I printed all of my examples on a Makerbot Replicator 5th Gen set to: Layers=0.20mm, Shells=2, Roof=.80mm, Floor=0.80mm, Fill=10%, Infill Pattern=Diamond (fast), Raft=Yes, Supports=No. Because of the simple geometry of the Box and the Pieces, these modest settings produce a very nice model in a relatively short print time. Please Note: Although I have not provided the solution here, I will respond to personal Thingiverse messages with questions about part sizes and/or printing accuracy. If you have trouble solving the puzzle once you have printed it, you can message me your email address, and I’ll send you the Solution Photo by return email. I will not use your email address for any other purpose, nor share it with anyone else. I promise. Feel free to contact me with questions, comments, or suggestions. I would also like to ask anyone who “Makes” this puzzle to thank me by taking a moment to respond with “I Made One” with your puzzle’s photo and your comments. But please, don’t publish your SOLUTION – it spoils the puzzle for others. Have Fun!
-mike- Instructions: I printed all the parts of the puzzle, using PLA Filament, on a MakerBot Replicator 5th Gen Printer using the following settings: Layer Height=0.20mm, Shells=2, Roof=.80mm, Floor=0.80mm, Fill=10%, Infill Pattern=Diamond (fast), Raft=Yes, Supports=No These settings produced a very nice puzzle in a reasonable amount of time. I put my finished puzzles in a small zip-lock bag with all the Pieces outside the Box. I added a little “Instruction Note”. The Note is included below. I’ve printed more than a dozen of these puzzles at this point – they make great gifts and are fun to keep around as table top toys for friends and family visitors. They each take about 4:30 to print. So far, none of them has required any post-print finishing. The Box Top fits easily onto the Box and is only required to easily store the puzzle when not in use. Install and remove the Box Top by pushing it straight down and pulling it straight up (and not by tilting it, which may break off one of the small ‘pins’). To make printing easier/faster, I included a single .stl file with all 7 Puzzle Pieces arranged to print together as a group, and I included a single .stl file with both the Box and Box Top arranged together. I also provided all of the separate .stl files.
-mike-

remixed_from.title: Heavy Duty Z-Axis tower for the MPCNC

title: Rigid Taller Z Tower for MPCNC - US version

description.text: If your stepper shaft is the longer variety (7/8" or 23mm), the standard Z Tower will not work. You need either this one for the US 3/4" conduit version or the one by Trudge for the IE 25mm version (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1292161). Actually, Allted created one of these (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:806241), but the thin sidewalls and columns didn't adhere well on my printer. It snapped when I installed it. So, I recreated the part from scratch with thicker walls and eliminated the oval cutouts to add rigidity. The picture shows the Allted design on the left (silver) and the remix on the right (red). I have tested this and it fits well. My Makerbot Replicator v5 seems to shrink holes, so I had to drill out the four motor mount holes and the bearing slot, but they are designed to exactly the same size as the original (3mm and 22mm, respectively). So, if you have had luck with the other MPCNC parts, it should work just fine for you. Let me know if you do have trouble and I will modify the design accordingly. As always, a big shout out to Allted for the incredible MPCNC!!

description.text: This is a working zipper mechanism.  I printed it as an experiment, inspired after the zipper on my wife's coat broke.  (I don't think I can print a replacement, yet.)  There might be applications to join small sections of a structure to make a large object, but mostly it's a toy.

Print two of the ZipperHalf parts and one ZipperY.  I sized it to fit well with my Thing-O-Matic using an original MK6 Stepstruder.  Clean up any stringers.  There may be some small chaff on the print, but manually interlocking the zipper teeth a couple times will allow the Y section to zip it fairly smoothly.
There's no provision to unzip it, just pull the two sections apart.
This works as is, but I marked it as a work in progress because once I get a MK7 Stepstruder I may try to make some refinements, including an unzip mechanism.

remixed_from.author: zennmaster
remixed_from.title: Z-probe holder for Makerfarm i3 with auto bed-level

description.text:
I tweaked zennmaster's OpenSCAD file to allow one to change the length of the piece and depth of the channel. I tweaked this since I was switching to the E3DV6 from the hexagon hotend, the former being slightly longer. Everything else is the same as zennmaster describes in his ABL blogs/videos: http://zennmaster.com/random-things/auto-bed-leveling-for-the-makerfarm-prusa-i3-part-1-assembly-and-basic-setup 2 variables at the top of the script:
add
deep The 'add' variable adds to the original length, and so is a relative change rather than an absolute. The 'deep' variable is the height of the base of the channel, so smaller is actually deeper. See also /r/shittyprogramming

layer_height = 0.1
number_of_layers = 12

Left and Right Drive Block for Makerbot Replicator 2x Dual Extruder, it works very well with filaments that have not constant diameter.
16/05/2017
file has been Updated with a new version 2
now the teflon tube entry is lower ( 7 mm ) and does not stress the filament or the tube.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2X

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

50

Notes: Print this file in the same position as downloaded, and only few supports will be created.
the file has big tolerances,so you'll need to use sandpaper only on few details.

The block will reuse all the metal components of the original Drive Block, only the small spring as to be replaced by a bigger spring from a common plastic peg. One of the screw that lock the block has to be cutted to make possible screw until the end.

title: Bahtinov Mask For Celestron C10-N (or other ~10" scopes)

description.text:
This is a large bahtinov mask that I designed for my Celestron C10-N telescope. The C10-N is a 10" newtonian, but the tube is actually 11" wide with a little space around all sides for the mirror. Since the build are on my printer is 10"x10"x10", I had to square off the design, and the corners are the only parts that stick out of the tube.
I printed one of these in PLA at 0.2mm layer thickness, and it is REALLY overbuilt. There's no need to build this quite so beefy, so consider scaling the Z axis down a bit if you make your own. I'd edit it, but I lost my original files to an SSD crash, and hate editing .STL files. :(
Hopefully someone else will find it useful though. :)

author: Myke974

description.text: If you do not know what this is, you do not need it. So do not download it and do not print it if you do not know what it is.

I had problems with moisture getting into my filament and causing little pops on the side of my prints. I realized when the problem did not occur with a fresh spool of filament that my filament was absorbing moisture. This Airtight Filament Canister solves the moisture problem and provides convenient storage. It includes three cradle designs which allow the filament spool to move freely. The filament is fed through an airtight connection using either 1/4" PTFE or 4mm PTFE tubing. You may use either the 1/4" PTFE connection or the 4mm PTFE connection. The canister is completely airtight except for the small hole in the end of the tubing where the filament exits. The hole is plugged by pushing the end of the tubing into the matching cap. If you would like your canister on a shelf above the printer, you may install the filament port on the side of the canister near the bottom. There are three versions of the cradle, a one piece design for narrower spools 53 - 70 mm, a one piece design for wider spools 63 mm - 80 mm and the newer adjustable 3 piece design. The adjustable cradle is better than the previous one piece designs. I suggest going with the adjustable cradle. See Update 5 below. The Rubbermaid container is a 21 cup size and can be bought at Amazon.com for $12.
http://www.amazon.com/Rubbermaid-1840750-Modular-Storage-Container/dp/B00BEUDWIC/ref=sr_1_2?ie=UTF8&qid=1455209151&sr=8-2&keywords=Rubbermaid+21+cup
PTFE Ports for 4mm and 0.250" tubing
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01IB81IHG
https://www.amazon.com/dp/B00AXAY47W The bearings can be bought anywhere including a skate shop and should cost around 75 cents each. The 1/4" PTFE is available from Home Depot. There is no other hardware for this design. 4mm PTFE is available on Amazon.com I've also included designs for 4mm and 0.250" PTFE tubing supports. Update 4-26-2017: Thanks to all who reported the pins being too tight. The cradle holes were 8 mm and the pins were also 8 mm (no clearance). I opened up the cradle holes to 8.3 mm and reduced the pins to 7.8 mm which should make the pins fit more easily. If yours are still tight, I suggest a bit of sanding of the pins. The new cradle and pin designs are V3. The filament port is the the same as before at version V2. Update 2-16-2017: I have added an alternate design for the PTFE port to support 4 mm tubing. The new design uses a cap and a clip rather than an integrate cap port. It uses the same spool cradles. I did this redesign so that I could better support CoreXY and HyperCube printers with a port mounted low on the container. You will need a 10mm PTFE connector and will need to drill a hole to mount the connector. See the photo. Update1: I have been using my new canister quite a bit this week and noticed that it feeds better if you face the canister and PTFE so it follows the natural curve of the filament coming off of the spool. (Makes sense doesn't it :)
Update2: I printed another one of these setups and I am keeping my favorite filaments in these canisters. It is much easier to hook them to my printer and it is easier to seal them off rather than zip lock bags which is how I store my other spools of filament. This canister has eliminated any problems I was having with moisture getting into my filament.
Update3: I received a spool of Hatchbox filament that did not fit the smaller of the two cradle designs so I narrowed the smaller one by 10mm. Between the two cradles, this canister design will support spools from 56mm through 80mm wide.
Update 4: I added a filament guide that mounts on the printer and receives the 0.25" PTFE guiding it to the middle of the top of the printer. This makes it easy to connect and to swap out canisters. You clip the filament, unplug the tubing and plug in another canister. Update 5: I have a new adjustable spool cradle which is better than my original one piece cradle also presented here. I have left the old cradle for those that like it. The new cradle is the yellow one and the STL files have "adjustable" in the name.
The complete information is here:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2394480 Update 6: I removed the printed port for 0.250" PTFE. I think the purchased ports are better and they are easier to install.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1 or 0.2mm

Infill:

40%

Notes: PLA
Extruder 200C
Bed 60C on Kapton Drill a 3/8" hole if you are using the 10mm PTFE connector and use two layers of Teflon tape to seal the connection. The fitting self threads into the soft plastic. You could probably leave off the Teflon tape and it would also seal fine.

Cleanup and Setup After printing the spool cradle, you may have to clean the holes with an 8 mm drill or a file.
The pins have a very small expansion on the end to retain them. If they can't be pushed in, you may have to sand them a small amount. My pins click into place firmly. The 21 cup Rubbermaid Container is part number 1840750. You will need to drill a 1/4" hole to one end of the cap and then use a step drill as shown to open it to 1/2". The step drill gives a clean not ragged hole. Glue both the filament port and the retaining bushing to the canister cap using Super Glue (for PLA). Clamp it in a vise or other method to create an airtight glue joint. Push 14-16" of 1/4" PTFE tubing into the open port. Set the cradle in the bottom of the canister and feed the filament from under the spool up through the port, tubing, and to your printer. When you're not using the filament, remove it from the printer and plug the open end of the feed tube into the sealed secondary port. You can also throw a couple bags of desiccant into the bottom of the canister. Your filament will stay nice and dry. You'll be surprised how many print problems are solved by eliminating moisture in the filament.

comments.text: I did not design the Tush++ cradle. It's possible that it doesn't work with the Rubbermaid container. My 3 piece cradle works fine. One tip is that some bearings have heavy grease inside keeping them from turning freely. I wash the grease out with WD-40 and then add a light oil like 3 in 1 Oil. As far as the 4mm/2mm tubing, everyone uses that tubing in their Bowden setups and I don't hear of any problems. Is it possible you received some bad tubing?
comments.author: esantoro

comments.text: I'm glad you mentioned that about the bearings. I use grease-less and caseless spinner bearings not designed for skateboards that spin very freely and have been experimenting with them. I'm happy that you confirm the need for bearings that spin more freely than the norm. I'm using only a 6cm section of tubing for the filament egress. It's not a scientific test, but I manually compared sliding filament through the regular Chinese 4mm/2mm PTFE that I'm using and Capricorn PTFE, and I could not decipher a difference in friction. Perhaps, I should try actually printing with the Capricorn PTFE in place.  My order of 4mm/3mm PTFE should arrive from China in three weeks.

author: jackxgreer

description.text:
I made this as part of a gift to hold blu ray movies, figured I'd share it here while I was at it. This was a last minute project idea I came up with and sort of designed while I printed stuff and just went back and forth like that. I should've designed it with less pieces but that would've required longer print times, and I had very little time to lose if something went wrong.
The assembly should be pretty straight forward but the lighting method is up to you. I used flexible led strips, with a remote led controller, and power supply. All bought on amazon. 
I've put in some basic info for printing and assembly in the post printing tab, but feel free to ask me any questions if you decide to make one and need some help.
The all parts in place STL is ONLY a guide for how everything fits together. It is not meant to be printed.

Print 2 of each Side Panel, Light Panel Frame, Light Panel Cover. Print 1 roof panel, back panel, bottom panel. Check the All Parts stl to see how everything fits together. I uploaded the design in a way that you can choose your own led's and wiring method as long as you have a dremel or other way to cut holes or slots in the inner and/or back panels for wiring. I've uploaded a picture of how I chose to run the lighting. I also glue white paper to the back of the lithopanes, and glued foil to the inside of the light panel covers to get consistent light coming through the lithopane. I used white PLA for the light panel frame to act as a diffuser/cover. I printed all panels directly on the bed so the pieces maintained a glossy finish and act as a reflector to illuminate the inside. For the lithopane, use a picture that is roughly 4:3 ratio VERTICAL. Customize using this one specifically: http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=229961. I used these settings:
invert colors = yes
layer_height = 0.01
lithophane_border = 2
height = 4
bottom_padding = 0.4
size = 137
When slicing, change the scale of X to .76 and leave Y and Z normal. I carefully used superglue to put it together only because I was on a time crunch to get it done and have't replaced my glue gun yet. The only residue visible is inside the box, but hot glue would be the way to go. Feel free to ask me any questions if you are making one. Lights facing towards each other all the way around, then facing up along the bottom. nearly complete picture of the inside of the box

Reviewing her color scheme, I managed to dissect the major colors into pieces allowing you to print her in color.

Printer Brand:

SeeMeCNC

Printer:

Rostock MAX

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

See notes

Notes: See Print Notes since Markdown doesn't appear to work properly here.

I doubled the size and corrected the model in Meshmixer before dissecting the pieces in Tinkercad.  I returned to Meshmixer for the troublesome body adding custom support to make it as clean of a print as possible.

I printed many failed pieces to get this right. She's head heavy so to get her to stand on her own pay attention to the infill settings of the pieces. Notice I use brims instead of rafts, that's a personal preference since it uses less plastic and I can print with little-to-no hair spray on a frosted glass plate. Fennekin-Body.stl - Yellow at 20% infill, no support necessary, my printer was choking on the feet and the Meshmixer support, so I created Fennekin-Body-Lozenge.stl that places an oval piece in the middle to calm the printer down and print better legs with less chance of failure. Fennekin-Ear-Left.stl & Fennekin-Ear-Right.stl - Red at 10% infill, use support. Fennekin-Eyes.stl - Red at 10% infill, no support or brim necessary. I used enamel model paint for the pupils. Fennekin-Head-Bottom.stl - White at 10% infill with support. Fennekin-Head-Crown.stl - Yellow at 10% infill with support. Fennekin-Tail-Base.stl - Yellow at 50%+ infill, no support. You want higher infill to act as a counterweight for the head. Fennekin-Tail-Tip.stl - Red at 50%+ infill, no support. Like the base, higher infill to act as a counterweight for the head. Assembly:

  • Remove support, clean and make sure all the pieces fit, you may not want to fully insert the posts for the head and tail until glued. I use a heat gun to soften crown and holes for better fit.

  • Glue the eyes and make them flush with the outer surface. If you are painting pupils on the eyes, I recommend doing that before gluing them in case you have to print new ones. Do'h!

  • Glue the tail tip to the tail base, there isn't a gap at the bottom so a generous drop or two at the bottom will suffice.

  • Glue the tail to the body, before affixing you'll notice the hole is not centered on the tail. Rotate the base of the tail where the larger portion is facing the rear to help with counterbalance.

  • Glue the crown of the head to the bottom of the head. Again, use a heat gun if necessary to get the top flush with the bottom.

  • Glue the head to the body.

  • Glue the ear inserts with a dab of glue in the hole and where it touches the inside wall of the ear. I use rubber bands to around the head to hold while curing.
    • If the head is still too heavy you can use the heat gun to soften the base of the head and body to pull the chin up, or just have her stand the front feet on a ledge.

author: freetrevor

remixed_from.author: Hydroslide
remixed_from.title: Dual Extruder Conversion - X Axis Carriage Adapter for Folger Prusa i3

description.text:
This is a minor revision of Hydroslide's dual extruder conversion plate/adapter.
In order to re-use the screws that originally mounted my MK8 extruder to the X carriage, which I believe are M3 x 40mm, I had to add spacers and washers between the motor and the conversion plate, to "use up" the extra screw length.  That was functional but not perfect, as it left the extruder assembly just kinda hanging out there by its upper mounting screws, not flush against the plate, which allowed the extruder to sorta bend or lever downward a bit.
Rather than make the whole plate thicker (as per a comment I made on the original model), which seemed wasteful, this revision adds 6 mm of additional height (essentially a built-in spacer) around the extruder mounting holes, and corresponding 6mm tall "feet" along the other edge of the plate, on which the bottom edge of the extruder motor can rest, rendering it effectively flush again.
Spacers + feet in this configuration has the added benefit of increasing the ventilation around the motor slightly.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

40%

Notes: Be very precise with your extrusion width, or your slicer may do weird things to the inside of the spacers (Slic3r, for example, wanted to double-extrude the inner-most lines). Also, it may look like the bottom "feet" nubs are off-center relative to the extruder mounting holes, but they're actually dead-on. Weird optical illusion!

description.text:
remixed mini-version of the Toolmaker`s Vise by jsteuben
my modifications:
-downscaled to fit with M5 screw and therefore new jaw opening/clamping width 50mm
-added some slots onto the vise body (for use small clamps instead of screws)
-new designed M5 knob
-added new type of vise body without holes but some groove on the jaw top to clamp thin parts
NOTE: the vise is designed to hold mainly plastic or wood parts for do some finishing work

you need:
1x M5 x40mm Screw (hexagon head)
1x M5 washer
1x M5 nut
-some sandpaper (may you need to clean-up the holes for the screw)
instructions:
press the M5 screw into the knob (heat- up the knob is another possibility)
press the M5 nut into the vise nut

Print info:
vise body and vise jaw includes some support already therefore use
0.2mm layer/Nozzle 0.4/shell thickness 0.8 washer/nut/knob printed with 0.1mm layer

This simple spool mount attaches to the top of your MendelMax. Super simple to use, and quick to change filament. I have only tested this with Ultimachine 5 pound spools, but this should work fine with any spool size. If you find a spool size that does not work with this, please let me know.

Print two copies. Attach loosely to the top of your MendelMax. Insert 20mm M8 or 3/4" 5/16" screws with one 608zz through each hole and fasten with a nut. Adjust so the filament spool fits properly, then tighten the screws.

comments.text: I found I needed to have the bearings on the inside of the spool mount rather than the outside, otherwise a full spool will ride on the frame of the spool mount rather than the bearings.

author: Cyborg_guy

title: Cyborg Geared Bowden Extruder - With Herringbone Gears and Simplified Hardware

description.text:
I really liked this extruder, but there were a couple of things I wished were different so I remixed it. I've replaced the gears with herringbone gears because I think they're more aesthetically pleasing, and I revised some of the hardware because I don't like ordering stuff that's not available locally. I had the 6001 bearings already, so I retained the M12 bolt.
The extruder will accommodate 1.75mm or 3mm filament, as long as you have the correct tube fitting and the bolt is hobbed correctly.
The M12 bolt is partially threaded, and the portion that the filament will pass over is part of the non-threaded portion so it can be hobbed easily.
The M8 bolt holding the 608 bearing in place is a regular cap head screw that I cut the head off of once it was in place. Otherwise it won't clear the main bearings. 
The body and idler parts are unmodified but I have included them anyway.
I hope this revision helps. It's a great design and I hope more people use it.

Bearings:
2x 6001 bearings
1x 608 bearings Bolts:
M8x20 (qty 1) - Holds the 608 bearing
M3x20 (qty 1) - Holds the idler to body
M3x55 (qty 2) - Tensioner Bolts
M12x60 (partially threaded) - Main hobbed bolt Nuts:
M12 (qty 1) - Nylon lock nut
M3 (qty 2) - Nylon lock nuts Other:
Two springs
M3 Washers (qty 4)
One standard NEMA17 stepper motor

Printer:

Monoprice Replicator 1 Clone

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

100

Notes: I used 100% infill for the gears with support. It's just for the center hub of the gear so it doesn't consume too much material.

author: CheeseCat

description.text:
The real model of my own brain out of MRI scan. Separated to seven parts that attach to each other by small magnets. Good for educational purposes.
Abreviations:
LH1 = Left hemisphere, part 1
LH2 = Left hemisphere, part 2
RH1 = Right Hemisphere, part 1
RH2 = Right Hemisphere, part 2
LC1 = Lt Cerebellum, part 1
LC2 = Lt Cerebellum, part 2
RC1 = Rt Cerebellum, part 1
RC2 = Rt Cerebellum, part 2
MR = Medula, Rt side
ML = Medulla, Lt side
compare100 and compare80 = a small test object for comparison of 80% and full resolution (see descriptions below)

Printer:

Prusa i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2 mm layer 0.4mm nozzle

Infill:

10-15%

Notes: The parts are cut so that they have a flat surface, so the need for support is minimized.
Use Meshmixer to generate support (select overhang angle of 20 Deg).

Some parts are cut in two parts but you have to glue them after print.
Some other parts are cut in two parts and you need to insert small magnets inside the holes.
Use 6mm magnets and glue them in the holes.
If you are going to downscale the model, beware that you will have to use smaller magnets.
There is a long hole in the medulla (the lowermost part). I glued a metallic tube of the proper size (out of an old telescopic antenna) in that place and mounted the whole brain on a metallic rod on a wooden plate.

First, I had an MRI scan of my brain (I am a staff radiologist at university hospital). Then I extracted the brain out of the MR scan using FSL software (other softwares also can be used).
Then I separated it into several parts to ease printing with minimal supports; and also to be able to disassemble the brain for educational purposes.
My original files were tremendously big; so I reduced the mesh density by Meshmixer.
This reduction caused about 10% lower quality and 90% lower file size.
I have included to small parts in the original size and reduced size for comparison (compare100 and compare80). Don't print these files. Just look at them and see how they are reduced.
If you really want to print the original high resolution version please leave a comment and ask me to send them by Email.

comments.author: snekooei

comments.text: Dude - I've been trying to print my brain MRI for 5 years - since I got a makerbot in 2010!   I've tried multiple types of software starting with osirix and other (dcom to stl programs)- but I can never figure out how to separate the bone/tissue from the brain for a clean STL -- or at least something I can clean up in meshlab.   Suggestions?
comments.author: waltorg

comments.text:
Dear Walter
For this purpose, you have to work with a few softwares and its not straight forward.
First of all, you need a high resolution MR scan. It must be "T1 weighted volumetric thin slices". In Siemens MR scanners the protocol is called "mprage".
Once you have this scan, in DICOM format, you are ready to go.
1- Convert the folder containing the scan, which typically consists of some 160 files, to NIFTI format. The best freeware tool for this is "MRIcroGL".
2- Remove tissues other than brain. The process is called "skull stripping". There are a bunch of softwares to do that; but the easiest way that I recommend is a free online service at http://volbrain.upv.es/.
You submit the nifti file (.nii) and they do skull stripping and also give you some data regarding volumes of different parts of your brain; whether they are normal or not, etc.!
3- 3DSlicer is the tool that you need for conversion of your skull stripped .nii file to stl format. It’s a free software but you will have to take some time to get familiar with it.
4- That’s it! Go ahead and do some editing in Meshmixer to get what you want.
Good Luck,
Sirous

description.text: Designed to retain the mobile end of the Z Cable Chain of the MPCNC machine. The two main parts are the Holder and the Leg. These parts are required should you only wish to have the anchor points for the Z carry Cable Chain. I have also added the Z Endstop, as a physical end stop for the max Z end stop switch. Some do not use this, but I find it very handy to be able to home all axis in one go to setup a new job!

Printer:

Devinci 1.0a

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3mm

Infill:

50%

Notes: Hardware required :- 2off M4 x 30Lg Bolts and 2off M4 Nyloc nuts and 4off 150mm cable ties
Should you use the Z Endstop print at the top you will also require :- 2off M4 x 20mmLg Bolts and 2off M4 Nyloc Nuts.
Just testing Meshmixer
